title: Suggesting Friends Using the Implicit Social Graph
segmentation: So this is work that was done in collaboration with my colleagues at the Googles Israel already center, but motivation.

My work is based on some research that was done by Paul Adams, whose user experience researcher at Google and what he did was he took a bunch of users in The Cave, them a list of all of our Contacts and the aspect to point each contact into a group, and he let the users creating groups and labels of however they wanted, and they created groups like Family in college friends, but we found is that by and large every single person created between three and five groups, and these groups didn't really have a lot of interest of overlaps.
The kryptonite affected.
And this is true across cultures with Alex very, very compelling.
But now if you're in the business of creating tools for electronic communication like we are in, this is not surprising for you because we know that user is interacting groups.
So if you're sharing photo album or planning parties, you probably have a very specific group of people in mind that you have hard data that is in communication here and now.
Obviously we want to create tools that can help users create persistent contact groups so that they can make this interaction, because here for them.
So the next time you're sharing the photo album with your family, you can just click on family instead of going in and doing all the people one after the other.
But the problem is that even though we've created these tools and other people have created these tools, by and large, nobody uses them.
And when we ask for using, why not?

They say things like creating groups, video service, time consuming on something that they don't usually point out that this is actually the case is that the group change overtime so the work that you've done to create your family group today next week when you want to share your photo album.
That report necessarily contain everyone that you wanted to contain all of the wrinkles and wasted.
So this is like researchers to become interested in the problem of automatically detecting leader Contacts on.
So instead of asking the users to go and create all these groups manually, we can help them by identifying who the groups are in their social network.
Now the previous approaches that people have taken to solving this problem is one of them.
Is graph clustering on the global social graph.
So looking at the graph with everyone is interacting with everyone else and saying that users are likely come along the same group if they have many friends in common.
Um, another approach that has has been done in the past is looking at content analysis.

So if you're exchanging a lot of emails with some people and you talk about your soccer team, that is likely that you belong to the same software team and we can say this is a group that exists in any social network.

The wait time is slightly different approach which is looking at identifying groups from communication patterns, so the insight that led us to this was noticing that email is inherently a group communication medium.

So people often send email to more than once again and the recipient list with their email isn't very carefully curated, so in fact the users are doing a lot of work of identifying groups of people when they send an email and Contacts from different groups are unlikely to appear as recipients in the same you know.
So for example, if I was to take my inbox and on one side and try to categorize all the messages and then once I put.
All emails from my coworkers on the other side put all the emails from my family.

I would end up with a lot of messages in the middle that contain met Mail that was to both my coworkers and my family, because in fact users interactions are implicitly doing the work with clustering their Contacts into groups.
Given this insight, we built the implicit social graph and Mrs Social Graph.
It's formed by users interactions with their Contacts so different from explicit social graphs in which user says this person is my friend.
This person is my friend.
This person is my friend, but instead anytime the two users are interacting with each other, in our case by sending an email so that forms an edge between the two of them.

We don't look at contents at all, and what forms is a weighted directed hypergraph?

Of the communication.

We call this implicit group.

It only takes into account interactions in which he was a direct participants.
So people who he's actually sent and received emails from the primary business.
We did those things to address privacy concerns, so that for each user we're analyzing only his inbox.
We're only showing him information that is based on an interaction that he said part of.
And we don't run the risk of exploding.
Kind of friend of friend information, telling people things that they're not supposed to know.

Now each user can interact with hundreds of groups or possibly thousands of Contacts, but many of these attractions are sporadic when they happen once, and they don't really carry a lot of weight and tell you very much about who is important to the user, and so when we're analyzing the you guys graph that it's very important to identify the context in groups that are most important to the user, and we do this by noticing 3 features that we can we can extract from users, email interactions that influence group importance.
So first of all, certain portions depends on the frequency and interaction, and this one is fairly obvious.
The more emails that you send and receive two person or figure people, the more likely they are to be important deal.

We also point out that recency is a big factor in importance, so interactions that you have today indicate a greater deal of importance or stronger relationship than emails that happened a few weeks ago.
A few months ago.
And finally, we think that the direction of the interaction is very important.

And this is because if you actively going to send an email to someone, then you're making up that you're taking an action, and that shows that they are important to you as opposed to passively receiving emails.
